newsitem.title: JAPAN: INTERVIEW - Scudder eyes investment trusts in Japan.
newsitem.headline: INTERVIEW - Scudder eyes investment trusts in Japan.

text.p: Scudder, Stevens & Clark Japan Inc says it plans to apply for a licence in a month or two to enter the lucrative investment trust business in Japan.

Masahiko Sasaki, president of the Japanese unit of American investment advisory firm Scudder, Stevens & Clark Inc, told Reuters in a recent interview that his company aims to launch investment trust operations in Japan by the end of this year.

"We are planning to apply for a licence in a month or two and aim to enter (the market) later this year," Sasaki said. By obtaining a licence from the Ministry of Finance, the company will be able to offer investment trust funds in Japan.

Sasaki said his company was considering offering up to six investment trusts at first, investing in Japanese stocks, U.S. assets, global stocks, global bonds, emerging markets' bonds and emerging markets' equities.

The firm has not decided whether it will form an alliance with other financial institutions, but has started exchanging opinions with other firms including insurance companies ahead of the planned easing of Japanese regulations to allow banks to sell securities investment trusts, Sasaki said.

As for fund management, Sasaki said his company would manage Japanese stocks by itself but ask its parent company to manage foreign-currency denominated assets. The management of foreign-currency denominated securities would be "a strategically important product" for the firm, he added.
Scudder is the latest among a growing number of foreign companies eager to enter the lucrative Japanese market amid the country's ongoing "Big Bang" deregulation of its financial markets.
